title: Could we create dark matter? - Rolf Landua

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of the matter in our universe is considered a mystery and is referred to as dark matter?
What is the name of the powerful particle collider in Geneva, Switzerland, where scientists are attempting to create dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: Large Electron Collider

options.label: B
options.text: Large Hadron Collider

options.label: C
options.text: Large Proton Collider

options.label: D
options.text: Large Quark Collider

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the detectors surrounding the collision points in the Large Hadron Collider?

options.label: A
options.text: To accelerate the proton beams to near the speed of light

options.label: B
options.text: To gather information on the new particles produced in the collisions

options.label: C
options.text: To determine the mass of the particles produced in the collisions

options.label: D
options.text: To separate the Higgs boson from other particles

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the long-theorized particle that was observed in 2012, and what is its significance in the search for dark matter?

options.label: A
options.text: Higgs boson, a particle that confirms the existence of dark matter

options.label: B
options.text: Higgs boson, a particle that is a precursor to the discovery of dark matter

options.label: C
options.text: Higgs boson, a particle that was discovered using the same methods being used to search for dark matter

options.label: D
options.text: Higgs boson, a particle that is unrelated to the search for dark matter

multiple-choice.question: What is the criterion for a result to be considered meaningful in the search for particles like dark matter at the Large Hadron Collider?

options.label: A
options.text: A bump in the graph that is slightly higher than the background

options.label: B
options.text: A bump in the graph that is significantly higher than the background

options.label: C
options.text: A bump in the graph that is lower than the background

options.label: D
options.text: A bump in the graph that is equal to the background

title: Why a total solar eclipse is such a big deal

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why we don't get eclipses every month, despite the moon's orbit around the Earth?

options.label: A
options.text: The moon's orbit is too slow.

options.label: B
options.text: The moon's orbit is not in line with Earth's orbit.

options.label: C
options.text: The moon's orbit is too fast.

options.label: D
options.text: The moon's orbit is too close to the Earth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the points where the moon's orbit crosses the sun's plane, which allows for eclipses to occur?

options.label: A
options.text: Nodes

options.label: B
options.text: Orbits

options.label: C
options.text: Shadows

options.label: D
options.text: Planes

multiple-choice.question: Why does the moon often turn red during a total lunar eclipse?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the Earth's atmosphere scatters the shorter, bluer wavelengths of light.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the moon's atmosphere scatters the shorter, bluer wavelengths of light.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sun's atmosphere scatters the longer, redder wavelengths of light.

multiple-choice.question: What is the reason why total solar eclipses seem much more rare than total lunar eclipses?

options.label: A
options.text: Totality lasts just a few minutes, and each one is only viewable by less than half a percent of Earth's surface.

options.label: B
options.text: Totality lasts for hours, and each one is viewable by the entire Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: Totality lasts for days, and each one is viewable by half of the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Totality lasts for weeks, and each one is viewable by a quarter of the Earth.

multiple-choice.question: Why will the Earth eventually only get annular and partial solar eclipses in the far future?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the moon is moving closer to the Earth.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the moon is moving further away from the Earth.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the sun is moving closer to the Earth.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the sun is moving further away from the Earth.

title: Will we ever be able to teleport? - Sajan Saini

multiple-choice.question: Is it possible to teleport a baseball from one location to another using quantum mechanics?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Yes, the information about the baseball can be sent and used to recreate it.

options.label: C
options.text: No, quantum mechanics does not allow for teleportation.

options.label: D
options.text: No, the technology to teleport objects does not yet exist.

options.label: A
options.text: The particle is too small to measure.

options.label: B
options.text: The particle is too large to measure.

options.label: C
options.text: Measuring the particle changes its quantum state.

options.label: D
options.text: Measuring the particle requires too much energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is quantum entanglement, and how does it relate to teleportation?

options.label: A
options.text: Quantum entanglement is a phenomenon where two particles become connected and can affect each other instantaneously, allowing for teleportation.

options.label: B
options.text: Quantum entanglement is a phenomenon where two particles become connected, but it does not allow for teleportation.

options.label: C
options.text: Quantum entanglement is a phenomenon where two particles become disconnected, allowing for teleportation.

options.label: D
options.text: Quantum entanglement is not related to teleportation.

multiple-choice.question: What is required to complete the teleportation process, in addition to quantum entanglement?

options.label: A
options.text: A digital message to help interpret the qubit at the receiving end.

options.label: B
options.text: A classical channel to transmit the qubit.

options.label: C
options.text: A quantum computer to process the qubit.

options.label: D
options.text: A physical connection between the two particles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current limitation of quantum teleportation, making it unlikely to be used for large objects?

options.label: A
options.text: The complexity of measuring the quantum states of large objects.

options.label: B
options.text: The energy required to teleport large objects.

options.label: C
options.text: The speed of light limiting the transmission of quantum information.

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above.

options.text: "Alex through the Looking Glass - How Life Reflects Numbers and Numbers Reflect Life"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Art of Cake Cutting"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Science of Baking"

title: The philosophy of Stoicism - Massimo Pigliucci

multiple-choice.question: What event led to Zeno of Cyprus developing the philosophy of Stoicism?

options.label: A
options.text: A major war in Athens

options.label: B
options.text: A shipwreck in Athens that left him stranded

options.label: C
options.text: A chance meeting with Socrates

options.label: D
options.text: A wealthy inheritance that allowed him to pursue philosophy

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the public colonnade where Zeno and his disciples gathered for discussion, which later became the name of the philosophy?

options.label: A
options.text: Stoa Poikile

options.label: B
options.text: Stoic Stadium

options.label: C
options.text: The Academy

options.label: D
options.text: The Lyceum

multiple-choice.question: According to Stoicism, what is the underlying structure of the universe that governs everything?

options.label: A
options.text: Chaos

options.label: B
options.text: Logos

options.label: C
options.text: Karma

options.label: D
options.text: Fate

multiple-choice.question: What are the four cardinal virtues that Stoicism emphasizes for personal improvement?

options.label: A
options.text: Practical wisdom, temperance, justice, and courage

options.label: B
options.text: Faith, hope, charity, and humility

options.label: C
options.text: Prudence, fortitude, justice, and temperance

options.label: D
options.text: Honesty, integrity, compassion, and fairness

multiple-choice.question: Which famous Stoic writer and Roman emperor used Stoicism to guide him through two major wars and personal losses?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Epictetus

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: What can you learn from ancient skeletons? - Farnaz Khatibi

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way researchers determine the age of a skeleton?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing the size and structure of the pelvic bones

options.label: B
options.text: By examining the condition of the teeth

options.label: C
options.text: By combining microscopic skeletal clues with the structure and size of bones like the clavicle

options.label: D
options.text: By analyzing the chemical compounds in bone collagen

multiple-choice.question: What can the condition of teeth reveal about an ancient individual?

options.label: A
options.text: Their age at death

options.label: B
options.text: Their gender

options.label: C
options.text: Factors like diet and malnutrition, which sometimes correlate with wealth or poverty

options.label: D
options.text: The location where they lived

multiple-choice.question: What do stable isotopes in bone collagen and tooth enamel vary among mammals dependent on?

options.label: A
options.text: Age and gender

options.label: B
options.text: Diet and location

options.label: C
options.text: Disease and health

options.label: D
options.text: Social status and wealth

multiple-choice.question: What can researchers learn from analyzing the isotope ratios in skeletons' tooth enamel?

options.label: A
options.text: The age and gender of the individual

options.label: B
options.text: The diet and location of the individual when they were young

options.label: C
options.text: The cause of death

options.label: D
options.text: The social status of the individual

multiple-choice.question: What is one way bio-anthropologists study skeletons to learn about cultural beliefs, social norms, wars, and what caused deaths?

options.label: A
options.text: By analyzing DNA from ancient remains

options.label: B
options.text: By examining the morphology of individual skeletons

options.label: C
options.text: By analyzing the similarities and differences among skeletons in cemeteries and mass graves

options.label: D
options.text: By studying the chemical compounds in bone collagen

title: Why do people join cults? - Janja Lalich

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a cult leader?

options.label: A
options.text: They are highly empathetic and genuinely care about their followers.

options.label: B
options.text: They are highly persuasive people with authoritarian and narcissistic streaks.

options.label: C
options.text: They are introverted and prefer to keep a low profile.

options.label: D
options.text: They are highly educated and have a strong academic background.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the internal conflict that cult members may experience when they start to doubt the cult's teachings?

options.label: A
options.text: Cognitive dissonance

options.label: B
options.text: Emotional distress

options.label: C
options.text: Psychological trauma

options.label: D
options.text: Social anxiety

multiple-choice.question: How do cults typically recruit new members?

options.label: A
options.text: Through aggressive marketing and advertising campaigns.

options.label: B
options.text: By targeting people who are new to an area or have recently experienced a personal loss.

options.label: C
options.text: By offering large sums of money or other material rewards.

options.label: D
options.text: By using coercion or force.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common tactic used by cults to control their members?

options.label: A
options.text: Encouraging critical thinking and independent decision-making.

options.label: B
options.text: Using techniques of coercive persuasion involving guilt, shame, and fear.

options.label: C
options.text: Providing members with access to a wide range of information and resources.

options.label: D
options.text: Allowing members to freely express their opinions and doubts.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of being a member of a cult?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased emotional intelligence and well-being.

options.label: B
options.text: Improved critical thinking and problem-solving skills.

options.label: C
options.text: Stunted psychological and emotional growth.

options.label: D
options.text: Increased financial stability and security.

options.label: B
options.text: 12 meters

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.text: It was a desert with very little life.

options.label: B
options.text: It had a large and diverse population of apex predators.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a frozen tundra with limited vegetation.

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Aquatic plants

options.label: C
options.text: Fish

options.label: D
options.text: Insects

options.label: A
options.text: A massive flood

options.label: B
options.text: A volcanic eruption

options.label: C
options.text: An asteroid impact, volcanic eruptions, and associated changes in climate

options.label: D
options.text: A disease pandemic

options.label: A

title: Why babies in medieval paintings look like ugly old men

multiple-choice.question: Why do medieval babies in art often appear as ugly, middle-aged men?

options.label: A
options.text: Medieval artists were not skilled at drawing babies.

options.label: B
options.text: The artists were trying to convey the idea that Jesus was born perfectly formed and unchanged.

options.label: C
options.text: The style was influenced by the Renaissance era.

options.label: D
options.text: The artists were trying to depict the harsh realities of medieval life.

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "homunculus" in Latin, and how does it relate to medieval art?

options.label: A
options.text: It means "little baby," and it refers to the depiction of babies in medieval art.

options.label: B
options.text: It means "little man," and it refers to the idea that Jesus was born perfectly formed and unchanged.

options.label: C
options.text: It means "beautiful art," and it refers to the style of medieval art.

options.label: D
options.text: It means "ugly baby," and it refers to the depiction of babies in medieval art.

multiple-choice.question: What was a major factor in the change of style from medieval to Renaissance art?

options.label: A
options.text: The discovery of new artistic techniques.

options.label: B
options.text: The influence of Greek and Roman art.

options.label: C
options.text: The rise of the Catholic Church.

options.label: D
options.text: The decline of the feudal system.

multiple-choice.question: How did the Renaissance era affect the depiction of babies in art?

options.label: A
options.text: Babies were depicted as more abstract and less realistic.

options.label: B
options.text: Babies were depicted as more realistic and cute.

options.label: C
options.text: Babies were depicted as more adult-like and serious.

options.label: D
options.text: Babies were not depicted at all in Renaissance art.

multiple-choice.question: What was a result of the increased wealth in cities like Florence during the Renaissance era?

options.label: A
options.text: Only churches could afford paintings.

options.label: B
options.text: People could not afford to have their babies painted.

options.label: C
options.text: People could afford to have their babies painted, and they wanted them to look cute and chubby.

options.label: D
options.text: The city became less interested in art.

title: Why don't perpetual motion machines ever work? - Netta Schramm

multiple-choice.question: What was the idea behind Bhaskara's design for a perpetual motion machine?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a machine that could convert heat energy into mechanical energy.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a machine that could harness the power of gravity to generate energy.

options.label: C
options.text: To create a wheel with curved reservoirs of mercury that would keep the wheel turning forever due to an imbalance in weight.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a machine that could convert electrical energy into mechanical energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why perpetual motion machines do not work?

options.label: A
options.text: They require an external energy source to function.

options.label: B
options.text: They violate one or more fundamental laws of thermodynamics.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too complex to build.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to maintain.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first law of thermodynamics?

options.label: A
options.text: Energy can be created or destroyed, but not converted from one form to another.

options.label: B
options.text: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted from one form to another.

options.label: C
options.text: Energy can be converted from one form to another, but not created or destroyed.

options.label: D
options.text: Energy can be created, but not destroyed.

multiple-choice.question: Why do machines that seem to achieve perpetual motion often fail?

options.label: A
options.text: They draw energy from an external source.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too efficient and produce no heat.

options.label: C
options.text: They are too simple and lack complexity.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too expensive to build.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of the second law of thermodynamics on perpetual motion machines?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to generate energy indefinitely.

options.label: B
options.text: It causes them to lose energy over time due to friction and heat.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on perpetual motion machines.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to convert energy from one form to another.

title: How the bendy straw was invented | Moments of Vision 12 - Jessica Oreck

multiple-choice.question: Where did Joseph B. Friedman and his daughter Judith have a moment that led to the invention of the flexible straw?

options.label: A
options.text: At home

options.label: B
options.text: In a park

options.label: C
options.text: In a soda parlor

options.label: D
options.text: At a hospital

options.label: A
options.text: To make it easier for children to drink milkshakes

options.label: B
options.text: To help patients drink while reclining in hospitals

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: He used a piece of dental floss to crush the paper between the threads of a screw

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: He heated the straw to bend it

multiple-choice.question: Who helped Joseph B. Friedman market and sell the flexible straw?

options.label: A
options.text: His daughter Judith

options.label: B
options.text: His sister Betty

options.label: C
options.text: A business partner

options.label: D
options.text: A marketing expert

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Joseph B. Friedman's invention of the flexible straw?

options.label: A
options.text: It became a rare and expensive item

options.label: B
options.text: It was only used in hospitals

options.label: C
options.text: It became a beloved utensil of every child and a regular household item

options.label: D
options.text: It was not successful

title: Who were the Vestal Virgins, and what was their job? - Peta Greenfield

multiple-choice.question: What was the punishment given to the Vestal Virgin who was found guilty of unchastity?

options.label: A
options.text: She was exiled from Rome.

options.label: B
options.text: She was forced to serve the goddess Vesta for an additional 10 years.

options.label: C
options.text: She was buried alive in an underground chamber.

options.label: D
options.text: She was forced to perform additional sacrifices.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the flame in the temple of Vesta?

options.label: A
options.text: It represented the power of the Roman gods.

options.label: B
options.text: It symbolized the continuation of Rome as a power in the world and the virginity of Vesta's priestesses.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a symbol of the goddess Vesta's wrath.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a reminder of the importance of sacrifices.

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the six-year-old girl who was chosen to be the next Vestal Virgin?

options.label: A
options.text: Vesta

options.label: B
options.text: Licinia

options.label: C
options.text: Julia

options.label: D
options.text: Aurelia

multiple-choice.question: What was the length of time that a Vestal Virgin was required to serve the goddess Vesta?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 years

options.label: B
options.text: 20 years

options.label: C
options.text: 30 years

options.label: D
options.text: For life

multiple-choice.question: What was the term used to describe the unchastity of a Vestal Virgin?

options.label: A
options.text: Incestum

options.label: B
options.text: Castitas

options.label: C
options.text: Sacrilegium

options.label: D
options.text: Impuritas
